Message.Title: A done deal?
Message.Msg: Looks like a done deal to me. Will Dell announce the offer tomorrow morning? Remember that this LBO talk started few months ago when DELL was trading around $9 per share so $13.5 was a generous offer. Of course that the world market has improved quit a bit and corporate spending will increase soon so PE is looking for value investment like DELL. Mike Dell will retain his shares in the private company and DELL will probably turn around in 2 yrs with $30 new IPO price. No one is here to lose money in this dog-eats-dog world. By the way, this is surely a done deal if big institutional shareholders are willing to accept $14 offer. But I think DELL will be sold for $16 per share. Looking to buy below $12 tomorrow. LOL....

Message.Title: Dell will NOT go private; this is a ploy
Message.Msg: Do you think Mike Dell will ever sell his company ??? Never. This is a ploy to pump up the sagging share price so insiders can make easy $$$, and when the announcement comes in 4 months to remain public, the stock trends back down to 11 bucks. I am long Google, Apple , and Amazon and IBM. I am short Avon, Pitney Bowes, HPQ, RSH, RIMM,NOK, and Sony

Topic.Title: Like CLEARWIRE, expect a SURPRISE second offer!!!! I BET its $19 to $20. Expect the unexpected, Musashi.

Message.Msg: I don’t see DELL being taken out for anything less than $20/sh. Dell’s PC business may not be making much... but overall... Dell is becoming a mini-IBM... Dell’s “normalized” earnings are around $1.40/sh... lower than previous years... still good... how can the stock only go to a p/e of 11... prev 10k shows Dell “. . . repurchased approximately 178 million shares of common stock for $2.7 billion during Fiscal 2012 . . .” That’s about 10% of the shs o/s. So why not just keep up the repurchases? Why the rush to sell? In the meantime, Dell pays a very sustainable .32/sh divident... or about 2.6% of share price... not a bad yield. If they want my shares north of $20... then fine... I can see HP or IBM stepping in.

Message.Title: Earnings
Message.Msg: If earnings from some of the big players lift the market today, DELL is going to jump another 6-8%, and if more rumours are leaked, its could jump %15-20. I don't know how people don't think the LBO is possible, or how they can't see how everything is being manipulated...even if the LBO does not happen, Dell was always an undervalued stock and is still good to be long in. Sure, its trading down AH, but surely this is based on Farber panic attacks...those of us with steady nerves know this baby is going to keep moving north...wish I had more money when I bought it at $9.55 in November...when you see a company with strong financials and near a 52 week low, well its investing 101 isn't it...the game is simple, buy low, sell high, right? Its just knowing what to buy low, and what to sell high...and right now, Dell is not at its high. I feel sad for all the shorts and those who bought into Farber and even the German's analysis...I don't see $20, but $17-18 is coming, congrats to those who have stayed put and bought more. Lets hope the earning are good, the market is up, and have fun watching Dell go green and into those pretty double digit % numbers that are so much fun to see on your screen.

Message.Title: Thought on my option trade
Message.Msg: Sold 4 2015 Jan $10 Jan covered Calls then used the proceeds to buy 10 May 2013 $12 calls...If the sale of dell goes down at $13.50...I will get $13.75/share assuming I only get $10 for the cover 2015 calls and the $12 calls are worth $1.50. If this goes out at $14 I would collect $15 per share...at $16 I collect $17.50...every additional dollar in the selling price I will make an extra $2.50/share. At $13.50 to $14 I make a little extra compared to just holding the shares, but anything above $14 it starts compounding...a little extra risk...but an increase in the reward

Message.Title: It´s fantastic . Dell with OPHELIA device on the cloud
Message.Msg: The trend in technology is for things to get smaller and more powerful — the pocket-sized smartphones of today have power that could best some of the biggest, most expensive computers of 10 years ago. Another trend that’s been taking root recently is the move toward the cloud, and Dell hasn’t been caught unaware. A new Dell device could be the game-changer that reverses falling sales in the PC unit, but the device is not necessarily a PC. Dell’s project, named “Ophelia,” is a cloud-computing USB device. In other words, the device plugs into a display and connects to the cloud via the Internet so all computing is done in the cloud and shot back to Ophelia to be displayed on whatever screen Ophelia is plugged into. There’s nothing else on the market quite like it, and Ophelia could change the way people think of computers — it could be the beginning of a revolution. Ophelia may be able to help Dell improve its cloud-based customer base, which consists mostly of federal and local governments. Dell could even reach the corporations it had been hoping to by pairing its cloud services and cloud-based computer and offering them to corporations that might otherwise seek cloud services from companies like Oracle (NASDAQ:ORCL). Though the new device hasn’t yet launched, still just running under a codename, Dell seems to be moving ahead on the project. Dell’s VP of cloud operations, Tarkan Maner, was even able to suggest a price-tag for the device of $50, which suggests it may be getting close to distribution. If Dell is successful with Ophelia, and no one else beats them to the punch, the company may become more appealing to firms considering the leveraged buyout, or Dell may even find itself in a position where it no longer needs to consider a buyout.

Message.Title: news
Message.Msg: Dell (NASDAQ: DELL) will most likely be acquired, but it won’t be easy, and there won’t be some huge premium paid for the company. However, the cost to acquire the company and the value that’s been created has supposedly already scared off TPG Capital, leaving Silver Lake as the sole suitor. If the deal is not complete then watch for significant selling pressure, as Dell has traded higher by more than 15% in the last three days due to the rumors and speculation.

Topic.Title: how is going private going to sell more computers?

Message.Msg: in an environment of historical low rates and tons of liquidity hunting for yields, the hurdle rate is probably pretty low to get attract money sitting around to do these sort of buyouts. True that PC business is not fundamentally sound, but I guess the thinking is that the sector has a long way to go before anyone can say it is dead, and while Dell still see $billions of cash flow + has decent cash balance at hand, structurally that makes a deal seem a bit less riskier. The end game is likely more layoffs, restructuring the company, selling off key assets (probably PC operations to say, a Chinese player) and re-branding Dell as to focus on enterprise - then relist. Above all, this deal is a product of excess market liquidity and low rate environment.
